narrative:
As the financial manager of our company, I carefully reviewed John's expense report for his recent 5-day business trip to New York City. The primary purpose of his visit was to attend critical business meetings with several key clients, which made the trip a qualifying expense under our company's accounting policies. According to the away from home test, John was away from his home for a period of time exceeding 14 days, so he was entitled to a per diem allowance for meals and lodging expenses incurred while traveling.

Upon reviewing John's expense report, I noticed that he claimed meals taken at a business restaurant with clients. These meals were considered ordinary and necessary expenses, as they were directly related to the business purpose of his trip and helped to foster relationships with our clients. The restaurant's receipt showed that the meals were reasonable in cost, and the associated entertainment expenses were minimal. I was satisfied that these meals were legitimate business expenses and approved them as such.

John also submitted receipts for lodging expenses at a hotel within the New York City area, which met the requirements for a qualifying business expense. His total expense report included a detailed breakdown of all business-related expenses, including transportation, meals, and lodging costs, which made it easier for me to verify the legitimacy of his claims. I was confident that his expenses were reasonable and directly related to the business purpose of his trip, so I approved his travel expense deduction in full.
